It could be a life long journey that requires passion, wisdom and spirit which is encapsulated in the choice of the lion. A conscious choice of image that also speaks of the nobility that exists within us all. This is a three-dimensional piece which literally leaps off the canvas. Thus demonstrating the path we all tread to find safety and community in a world that can often seem a fight to the death.

Title: Like a Real Greenhouse
How it connects to the theme of Shelter: I made a model greenhouse to look like a real one, like the one in my old garden. I also made model birds to sit on top. I like growing plants and seeing birds, bees and butterflies around. I put a model of me inside resting on a deck chair like I’m on holiday in a hot country like Turkey, Greece or Spain. I feel warm and happy when I grow plants in the greenhouse and like I’m doing a job. It gives me something to do and I can make extra plants for the garden and to eat in my home. I once grew a 10ft tall sunflower. All my neighbours said they could see the sunflower growing over the fence. When it died I had 500 sunflower seeds that I fed to the birds and saved some to grow more flowers the next year.

Title: Unapologetically Queer
How it connects to the theme of Shelter: Being queer means you get to thrive in your chosen family. Your chosen family are your shelter from the storms that can rain upon you as a queer person. Your chosen family is a sanctuary where LGBTQ+ people can heal, thrive, and access support that affirms their identities and addresses the unique challenges they face. By providing a nurturing, inclusive, and supportive environment, chosen families make a profound difference in the lives of LGBTQ+ individuals seeking much needed shelter.

Title: Nesting: Regulation Station
Content: A heavy and strong nest smelling of friendly sheep is filled with a mini blanket and very small woolly book to provide a safe space that regulates and recharges the tiny woolly brain.\n Crocheted with nearly one kilo of pure, undyed Scottish wool sourced from small producers around Scotland.
How it connects to the theme of Shelter: As an autistic artist who is chronically ill, disabled and in recovery from c-PTSD, "nesting" (sheltering for regulation) is one of the most important forms of self-care to stay functional in a world and body that are recurringly challenging. I wanted to convey a feeling of comfort, safety and protection with the woolly nest. It is heavy and smells of sheep, which is a deeply soothing smell. A miniature blanket provides relaxation and warmth to rest. Books are a mainstay of my life and have been instrumental to preserving my mental health in times of trauma, so there is a tiny woolly book in the nest. The minuscule brain represents the main recipient of this healing and recharging time. The tiny blanket, the book and brain are humourous nods to much larger pieces and sensory sculptures I have crocheted with Scottish wool.

Title: Holding you tight
Content: Coloured pencil on black paper. The best hug in the world
How it connects to the theme of Shelter: Coloured pencil on black paper. A drawing of protection and love

Title: Too Weak to Stand
Content: This artwork, is based on my time on the island of Lesbos when the Syrian refugees were fleeing for safety. This woman was too weak to stand although she was at the shoreline. Her traditional clothing didn’t help and only the men appeared to have life jackets that day. As I held her in my arms and gave her water she just murmured, then the stretcher arrived.
How it connects to the theme of Shelter: Too Weak to stand describes the plight of the woman being washed up on the shore of Lesbos. Fleeing from war torn Syria, thrown overboard from a sinking boat by men. She had managed to swim to shelter, but too weak to stand on the shore and in fear of drowning.

Title: A Seat at the Table
Content:
A Seat at the Table
 Digital Illustration, 2018
 Created and described by Hatiye Garip.
 https://hatiyegarip.com
 A showcase of accessible illustrations in the voices of the illustrators.
 Accessible Lines is coming soon! 
 
 Listen the audio description of "A Seat at the Table" here:
 https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZY6JfhQpL-M
 
 The project is led by Hatiye Garip and funded by the British Council.
 
 Audio Description Training delivered by Anne Hornsby from Mind's Eye.
 
 Proofreading by Zeynep Şölen Yıldız.
 
 Proofreading, Sound Design, Arrangements and Audio Production by Paddy Johnston.
 
 Advice on Sound Design provided by Peter Bosher.
 
 Animations and Videos created by Tolga Sertkaya.
How it connects to the theme of Shelter: This is a piece of artwork that made me start to include representations of disability in my work. Years later, I made this artwork accessible through audio description through the Accessible Lines project. I made peace with my disability, I was proud of it, and over time I found a shelter for myself by being interested in accessible art.

Title: Shelter Boy
Content:
“Shelter boy” depicts an orphan refugee who’s lost everything and fleeing from an hellish war, hoping he’s safe in his shelter. He’s very scared and lonely and crying, his only safe place of refuge is the shelter. That provides protection safety and sanctuary from the war torn outside world.
  The boy suffers from post traumatic stress disorder, from what he as witnessed in the war, “I hope you can see this in his eyes”, and he his grieving for his family, he’s hungry and very tired. All the boy needs is love food and water and somewhere to be safe.
  Nothing material would matter to him, it’s very heart breaking to see what the boy has gone through and I hope he gets the help he needs. One day he might have a new family and a loving shelter called a home.
 My own life has been one big shelter .
How it connects to the theme of Shelter:
“Shelter boy” depicts an orphan refugee who’s lost everything and fleeing from an hellish war, hoping he’s safe in his shelter. He’s very scared and lonely and crying, his only safe place of refuge is the shelter. That provides protection safety and sanctuary from the war torn outside world.
 
 The boy suffers from post traumatic stress disorder, from what he as witnessed in the war, “I hope you can see this in his eyes”, and he his grieving for his family, he’s hungry and very tired. All the boy needs is love food and water and somewhere to be safe.
 
 Nothing material would matter to him, it’s very heart breaking to see what the boy has gone through and I hope he gets the help he needs. One day he might have a new family and a loving shelter called a home.

Title: Untitled #135
Content: Fine art photography prints are available for this image. Please contact me via email for more details:\n infoatmos.art
How it connects to the theme of Shelter: This artwork links to the theme of Shelter as the subject is one of the Coventry University buildings. This building offers a shelter for those working and studying in an academic capacity.

Title: The Broken Cup
Content: Analogue paper collage 2023.\n A girl does a handstand, oblivious to the broken cup beneath her and her mother's pained expression as she watches her from a knife edge.\n This collage is a visual representation of the experience of domestic violence. The map represents the unknown locations of refuges a woman might be moved to in order to ensure her safety; the image of the cut flower is a metaphor for the gesture of apology, which soon dies away, leaving the cycle to start all over again.
How it connects to the theme of Shelter: A girl does a handstand, oblivious to the broken cup beneath her and her mother's pained expression as she watches her from a knife edge.\n This collage is a visual representation of the experience of domestic violence, the breaking of trust and of spirit. The map represents the unknown locations a person might be displaced to, when their home is no longer a place of shelter or safety. The image of the cut flower is a metaphor for the gesture of apology, which soon dies away, leaving the cycle to start all over again.

Title: ASH.
Content: This picture is about the suffering of elderly people, lonely, left in destroyed villages in the territories of Russian aggression against Ukraine. The drawing is created in the style of surrealism and expressionism.
How it connects to the theme of Shelter: This picture is about the suffering of elderly people, lonely, left in destroyed villages in the territories of Russian aggression against Ukraine. This picture is the first and main one from the series "Ashes." which now consists of 6 drawings and I continue it. The drawing is created in the style of surrealism and expressionism.

Title: Untitled (Grapes)
Content: This was a project I wanted to use to explore different colour schemes. I wanted to deviate from the normal true-tone colour scheme and create my own to feel more confident using other colours going forward. \n The use of nature/plants in my work was inspired by the French art movement known as Rococo. Whilst the word is in relation to the ornamental painting of ceilings and roofs of European institutions, Rococo also served as a means of creating paintings to exhibit the luxuries and complexities of life in the 18th Century. I wanted to incorporate this in my own unique way.
How it connects to the theme of Shelter: This piece is created with a safe haven in mind (whether dreamt or sought after). The subject in question is quite relaxed, surrounded by grapes attached to vines. The subject feels comfortable and at peace away from the real world problems and creates their own safe space amongst nature.

Title: Polish Flag - Reworked
Content:
I reinterpreted the Polish flag as a symbol of political protest, focusing on identity, national consciousness, and the urgent fight for women's rights, particularly in the context of restrictive abortion laws. Created during the Polish parliamentary elections, this piece reflects a moment of unity and defiance against gender-based violence and the ongoing struggle for democracy. 
 While participating in the Million Hearts March, I observed how, in moments of collective political solidarity, people often turn to creative expression—crafting banners, political signs, or inventing slogans. Inspired by these observations, I recreated the process of making a banner, focusing on the spontaneity and emotions tied to that moment, and I created a canvas that serves as a political manifesto. 
 
 This work reinterprets shelter as a symbolic and emotional space created through collective resistance and solidarity. The banner, inspired by the Polish flag, becomes a transient safe haven where marginalized voices unite to fight for safety, rights, and belonging. It highlights how shelter can exist in shared action and the courage to stand against oppression.
How it connects to the theme of Shelter: I reinterpreted the Polish flag as a symbol of political protest, focusing on identity, national consciousness, and the urgent fight for women's rights, particularly in the context of restrictive abortion laws. Created during the Polish parliamentary elections, this piece was inspired by my participation in the Million Hearts March, where I observed how collective political solidarity often sparks creative expression—crafting banners, signs, or slogans. Drawing from these observations, I recreated the process of making a banner, focusing on the spontaneity and emotions of the moment. This work reinterprets shelter as a symbolic and emotional space of resistance and solidarity, offering a transient safe haven where marginalized voices unite to fight for safety, rights, and belonging. It highlights how shelter can exist in shared action and the courage to stand against oppression.
